LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  The People's Republic of China (PRC) 
   
Classification  Thematic: Economic growth 
   
Environment  Category A. An environmental impact assessment was undertaken, and the 
Assessment  summary was circulated to the Board on 29 May 2002. 
   
Project  The Project is located in Shanxi, a relatively poor midwestern province of the 
Description  PRC with a per capita gross domestic product (2000) at 61% of the national 
average. The Project will (i) construct a new expressway and a bridge over 
the Yellow River (Huang He); (ii) improve local roads servicing poor counties 
and townships; and (iii) provide consulting services and training to enhance 
construction  quality,  road  safety,  vehicle  emissions  control,  and  project 
monitoring  and  evaluation.  The  project  expressway  supports  the  PRC's 
Western Region Development Strategy, which aims to promote economic 
growth, reduce development disparities between the western and coastal 
regions, and improve natural resources management. 
   
Rationale  The Project supports the national trunk highway system, one of the important 
priorities of the PRC Government. It is a system of interprovincial expressways 
and high-class highways of about 35,000 kilometers (km), to be constructed 
over a 20-year period up to 2010. The PRC road network is underdeveloped in 
both quality and extent with less than 3% classified as expressways or Class I 
highways, and about 14% as Class II highways. Large parts of the country, 
particularly  poor  inland  areas  such  as  Shanxi  Province,  do  not  have 
developed roads, restricting access to markets and social services.  Thus, 
road development is a key component in the Government’s strategy to provide 
needed infrastructure to facilitate economic growth and reduce poverty through 
improved access to markets and services.  
   
The  proposed  expressway  will  (i) serve  part  of  the  vital  Taiyuan-Xi'an 
Corridor (Inner Mongolia to Yunnan Province, 3,610 km) of the national trunk 
highway system, passing through several cities in different provinces; (ii) 
reduce congestion on national highway G108; (iii) serve as an important link 
to  other  neighboring  provinces  by  acting  as  a  catalyst  in  promoting 
interprovincial  trade  and  fostering  new  economic  activities  through  the 
construction of the Yellow River Bridge; (iv) improve the rural poor’s access 
to effective means of transport for meeting livelihood needs by enhancing 
mobility and linking poor areas to growth centers providing market access, 
employment opportunities, and better social services by expanding local 
roads; (v) improve efficiency of both road passenger and freight operations 
and  reduce  transport  costs,  congestion,  noise,  accidents,  and  vehicle 
emissions;  (vi)  promote  private  sector  investments  from  domestic  and 
international sources by improving road accessibility; and (vii) boost further 
investments in Shanxi, which will create demand for goods and services 
provided by the people in remote areas.

There are no major environmental and resettlement risks and adequate

While a financial risk is associated with construction and operation of the 
expressway, its extent will depend upon the actual construction costs. To

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Shanxi Road Development II Project. The 
project framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
2.  The Government continues to have a multipronged approach to development. Road 
development is a key component in the development strategy to improve access to markets and 
services. The government policies for road development are based on the following principles: 
(i) constructing expressways to expand the national trunk highway system (NTHS) to link all 
cities with a population of more than 500,000; (ii) developing secondary roads, particularly those 
that  will  help  reduce  poverty  and  promote  rural  markets;  (iii) promoting  trade,  economic 
activities, commerce, and other sociocultural links among various provinces; and (iv) building 
roads  that  will  support  regional  cooperation  with  neighboring  countries  in  the  southwest, 
northeast, and northwest. In the PRC, the heart of the road network is the NTHS, a system of 
interprovincial expressways and high-class highways of about 35,000 kilometers (km), to be 
constructed over a 20-year period up to 2010 (Map 1). As part of a multipronged approach to 
road sector development, the Government’s strategy also includes the development of local 
roads. These are consistent with the Western Region Development Strategy, which is a key 
theme of the 10th Five-Year Plan (2001–2005). This Strategy aims to promote economic growth, 
reduce disparities between the western1 and coastal regions, and improve environmental and 
natural resources management. The road sector forms an important part of this Strategy as it 
provides a vital link between the western and coastal regions. The Project will support the 
Government's NTHS and the Strategy, as part of an important artery of the Taiyuan-Xi'an 
corridor. Detailed analyses of the road subsector and ongoing policy reforms in the subsector 
are given in Supplementary Appendix A. 
 
3.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) operational strategy2 in the PRC’s road subsector 
supports (i) construction of roads that connect major growth centers and promote linkages with 
hinterland economies; (ii) integration of the network so that the NTHS is supported by a system 
of local roads, particularly those that provide access to poor areas; (iii) promotion of road safety; 
(iv) institutional  strengthening  to  increase  the  commercial  orientation  and  efficiency  of 
expressway organizations; (v) improvement of highway planning and evaluation techniques; 
(vi) adoption of appropriate pricing policies to ensure optimum use of road transport capacity; 
and  (vii) use  of  alternative  methods  of  investment  financing,  including  private  sector 
participation. The strategy reflects an integrated approach for the development of the road 
sector by considering not only expressway and highway systems, but also local roads servicing 
poorer segments of the population.  
 
4.   External assistance to the road subsector has come mainly from ADB, Japan Bank for 
International  Cooperation  (JBIC),  and  the  World  Bank.  Since  1985,  the  World  Bank  has 
provided about $5.3 billion to finance 22 highway projects and six urban transport projects. JBIC 
has provided about $990 million equivalent for six bridge projects and five highway projects in 
the NTHS. Since 1991, ADB has provided 21 loans totaling nearly $3.9 billion to finance 
3,115 km of highway development, together with the associated 5,042 km local road network,

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
6.  The  PRC  road  network  is  underdeveloped  in  both  quality  and  extent.  Despite 
considerable investments in recent years, expressways and Class I highways still account for 
less than 3% of the total road network, and Class II highways for about 14%.4 The remaining 
83% are medium- to low-grade paved roads and gravel roads. Large parts of the country, 
particularly the poor inland areas, including those in Shanxi Province, do not have access to 
markets and adequate social infrastructure. These observations were confirmed during public 
consultations that were carried out during project preparation. A chronology is given in Appendix 
4 and more details are given in Supplementary Appendix B. Due to the rapid growth of the PRC 
economy since 1978, the demand for transport services has increased many fold. Furthermore, 
the number of privately owned motor vehicles in the PRC increased more than 20 times during 
1985–2000, from 0.3 to 6.3 million vehicles. However, the country’s transport capacity is still 
very limited. Thus, serious constraints remain, especially in the road subsector. As a major 
element in the integrated approach to road development, local roads have been included in the 
project scope. This also makes ADB’s intervention in the road subsector more effective in terms 
of poverty reduction (Supplementary Appendix C). 
 
7.  The PRC's road investment needs from 1996 to 2010 are estimated at $504 billion. 
Available revenues are estimated at $302 billion from road user charges, and $29 billion from 
toll collections, leaving a financing gap of $173 billion or about $12 billion per year. Consistent 
with ADB's policy dialogue, the Government is creating a framework to attract private sector 
finance for road construction. While the private sector is willing to participate under concession 
agreements, or in refinancing, leasing, and securitization, it has been difficult to finance build-
operate-transfer (BOT) type projects, which entail the private sector taking the initial risks of

8.  The Project is consistent with ADB’s country operational strategy and the Government’s 
policies and strategies. It reflects an integrated approach to road transport sector development 
as a component of overall economic development. It will connect economic growth centers in 
Shanxi, through the expressway and bridges component, and support the development of local 
roads that will provide the local poor with access to economic centers. The Project will serve as 
a vital part of the Taiyuan-Xi'an corridor of the NTHS. It connects to the 176 km Qixian-Linfen 
Expressway under Loan 1701-PRC: Shanxi Road Development Project through the 40 km 
Linfen-Houma Expressway (financed by the local government), which is expected to open to 
traffic in December 2002. The Project also links to the 176 km Yumenkou-Yanliang Expressway 
under Loan 1838-PRC: Shaanxi Roads Development Project. Therefore, once the proposed 65 
km Houma-Yumenkou Expressway, including the Yellow River Bridge under the Project, is built, 
about 457 km of the Taiyuan-Xi'an corridor, from Qixian in Shanxi to Yanliang in Shaanxi, will be 
completed (Map 2).  
 
9.  As a result of recent rapid economic growth, between 1990 and 2000 road passenger 
traffic in Shanxi increased from 5.9 billion to 13.6 billion passenger-km. This corresponds to an 
average annual growth rate of 8.7%. Road freight traffic in Shanxi Province increased from 
11.5 billion to 27.0 billion ton-km, or an average annual growth rate of 8.9% over the same 
period. In contrast, the national growth rates were 9.7% and 5.9%, respectively, over the same 
period. Keeping abreast with the 20-fold national increase, privately owned motor vehicles in 
Shanxi totaled about 235,078 in 2000.  Increased demand for transport services has not been 
matched by expansion in the road subsector. Two railroads are currently operating in the project 
area: the South Tong-Pu Railway and the Huo-Xi Railroad. The Hou-Xi Railroad, running from 
Houma to Xi'an in Shaanxi Province, is parallel to the project expressway. These do not, 
though, meet the expanding transport requirements. The Hou-Xi Railroad carried 2.2 million 
passengers and 8.2 million tons of freight in 1996. 
 
10.  Despite the rapid increase in the total number of vehicles, Shanxi has only about 1.7 
vehicles (trucks, cars, or buses) for 100 persons. Modernization of the vehicle fleet is needed to 
improve vehicle safety and reduce fuel consumption and vehicle emissions. In Shanxi, road 
maintenance fees and domestic borrowing are major financing sources for the budget. An 
increasing proportion of provincial road budgets is being used to meet the national priority for 
expressway and highway construction.  Given the PRC's rapid economic growth and vehicle 
ownership, both the public and private vehicle fleets are expected to continue to grow rapidly in 
the coming years. In Shanxi, annual traffic volume growth in 2000–2001 was about 9.4%, with a 
rising trend. This will result in substantial increases in the volume of road traffic and mounting 
congestion.  
 
11.  ADB has been actively involved in policy dialogue on the PRC road subsector since 
1991. Recently, the principal issues addressed include the poverty reduction impact of road 
projects, highway design standards and construction quality, road safety, vehicle emissions, 
pricing  policies,  commercialization  and  corporatization,  and  nongovernment  financing 
resources. The current status and achievements to date are summarized in the Road Subsector 
Policy Reform Plan. The Plan and a summary of the road sector analysis are given in Appendix 
5. 
 
12.  ADB evaluation shows high levels of performance for ongoing transport projects and 
TAs in the PRC. The maintenance of roads completed under ADB-financed projects has not 
been a problem in the country. An effective budgetary allocation system is in place, and strong 
institutional capacity to maintain the expressway system has been developed. Recent TAs have

4  
 
been instrumental in focusing the Government's attention on the need to expand its sources of 
finance for highway development, as well as on the institutional, policy, and regulatory issues 
that need to be addressed to facilitate the use of a broader set of modalities for domestic and 
foreign resource mobilization. An ADB-financed study helped the Government identify road 
projects and capacity-building activities in the southwest region for implementation during the 
10th Five-Year Plan period. This shift in policy direction is in line with ADB's strategic objective of 
reducing poverty in inland provinces.  
 
13.  By maintaining dialogue integral to TA and loan activities, ADB has ensured that its 
operations are consistent with the Government's road subsector policy reform. Hence the 
Project adds dimension to the traditional road project concept. Through an integrated approach, 
it brings the usual benefits associated with a road project. It will improve the efficiency of both 
road passenger and freight operations through reducing  transport costs, traffic congestion, 
traffic noise, traffic accidents, and vehicle emissions, and through increasing service frequency. 
Through the local roads component, it will also improve access of the poor to effective means of 
transport  for  meeting  their  livelihood  needs  through  enhancing  the  mobility  of  poor  rural 
households, thereby increasing market opportunities and social services (such as access of the 
sick and injured to health facilities). It will also boost investments, since lack of roads and poor 
accessibility are among the most frequently cited impediments faced by international and 
domestic sources to invest in poor interior provinces.5  
 
14.  An integrated approach extends these benefits and brings the Project into the larger 
development needs of the province and the region. The Project goes beyond the project area by 
providing a vital link to the rest of the country through both its expressway and local roads 
components. It will facilitate interprovincial trade, improve transport services in urban areas, and 
connect poorer rural areas to vital growth corridors. It will connect people from two provinces, 
through the Yellow River Bridge component, resulting in the revival of social and cultural links 
while promoting economic development. The Project also brings technology, evident in the 
Yellow River Bridge being the largest ADB-financed bridge in the PRC using state-of-the-art 
construction skills and technologies, thereby raising standards in road projects. In view of the 
need for institutional strengthening, the Project will endorse capacity building in construction 
supervision,  project  quality  control,  road  safety  measures,  and  performance  monitoring 
activities. The Project integrates road and transport development into the broader context of 
economic and human development, by increasing access and connectivity between areas, 
peoples, and ideas.  
 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Objectives 
 
15.  Shanxi Province is a relatively poor interior province located in the midwestern part of  
the PRC. Shanxi had around 1.7 million rural poor by the end of 2000, based on an annual 
income of CNY1,000 per person. This accounts for about 7.5% of the rural population of Shanxi 
province of 22.7 million.6 In 2000, the average gross domestic product (GDP) per capita in 
Shanxi  was  CNY4,285,  or  about  61%  of  the  national  average  (CNY7,079).  Since  1980, 
economic growth in Shanxi has, at an average of 9.2% per annum, been slightly lower than the 
national  average  of  10.1%  per  annum.  The  Project  will  reduce  transport  costs,  promote 
economic development, and reduce poverty through improved rural activities and employment 
generation in the project area. As a result of the ADB’s policy dialogue, the scope of the Project 
has been expanded to strengthen its development impact through a local roads component to 
improve the access of poor communities in the project area. The Project involves building an

B.  Economic Benefits  
 
41.   An economic internal rate of return (EIRR) was calculated based on a comparison of the 
with-  and  without-project  situations.  The  economic  costs  of  the  project  roads  include  the 
resource costs for construction, operation and maintenance (O&M), resettlement, and the value 
of agricultural production from land lost permanently. Allowance has been made for the costs of 
equipment replacement, road maintenance, and minor improvements to the network without the 
Project. The economic benefits generated by the project roads include (i) vehicle operating cost 
(VOC) and time savings for those who remain on their original routes, (ii) VOC and time savings 
for those who choose to pay the toll and divert to the new road, (iii) VOC savings on the 
improved local road network, (iv) benefits from generated traffic, (v) savings from the reduction 
of direct and indirect costs of accidents, (vi) working capital savings to freight in transit, and 
(vii) resource cost savings arising from diversions from rail to road. Environmental benefits will 
come from avoided vehicular emissions as a result of the reduced level of congestion on 
national highway G108. However, these benefits were not included in the analysis due to 
difficulties in quantification. Economic costs and benefits have been valued in 2002 economic 
prices.  Results  are  summarized  in  Appendix  14  and  details  are  given  in  Supplementary 
Appendix N. 
 
42.   The EIRR for the Project is 16.2%, indicating that the Project is economically viable. The 
EIRRs of the expressway and the local roads component are 16.0% and 21.6%, respectively. 
Results  of  sensitivity  analysis  confirm  the  robustness  of  the  Project's  economic  viability. 
Changes in the key variables, such as a 20% reduction in VOC savings and growth rate of 
normal traffic and a 20% increase in costs, do not significantly impact the economic viability. 
The capital cost would have to increase by about 48% over the base estimate for the EIRR to 
fall below 12%. The benefit level would have to decrease by more than 32% to achieve the 
same effect. Given previous experience in the PRC, variations of such magnitude are unlikely.

3.  Poverty Reduction Impacts 
 
45.  The impact of transport infrastructure investments on poverty reduction is demonstrated 
by recent studies using an econometric model that examined the effectiveness of government 
expenditure in various sectors in contributing to growth and poverty reduction in the PRC and 
Indonesia.14 The studies concluded that, compared to other sectors, such as irrigation, soil and 
water, power, education, and health, government expenditure on roads has the largest impact 
on  poverty  reduction,  productivity,  and  growth.  Infrastructure  is  a  precondition  for  poverty 
reduction. The research report on the PRC also suggests that, similar to education, the large 
impact of rural infrastructure on poverty comes mainly from improved employment opportunities 
(in addition to the impact on agricultural growth). Labor is the major resource of the poor. To be 
able to capitalize on their major asset, the poor need to have access to jobs and to be able to 
transport the goods that they produce to markets. Roads for poor rural areas lower transport 
costs, reduce the cost of inputs, improve access to services and jobs, and therefore improve 
farming practices; they also provide better access to health and education.

E.  Project Risks 
 
54.   The Project has been formulated to reduce potential technical and economic risks. The 
main technical risks, which could result in implementation delays and changes in the cost 
estimates, are associated with the construction of the Yellow River Bridge and 11 large bridges. 
To mitigate these risks, consultants have reviewed the proposed construction methods. The 
prequalification of contractors will focus on their financial and technical capability in handling 
similar works. During the construction period, monitoring and contract management information 
systems will be set up and implemented with the assistance of the international consultants for 
timely identification of technical problems and implementation of corrective measures. There are 
no  major  resettlement  risks;  adequate  mitigation  plans,  and  implementation  capacity  and 
monitoring mechanisms will be put in place for resettlement. 
 
55.   Economic performance of the project implementation agency would have to deteriorate 
substantially for the Project to cease being economically viable. Sensitivity analysis indicates 
that the economic benefits of the Project are stable. While a financial risk is associated with

costs. To mitigate this financial risk, SHEC is consciously oriented to building up a commercial 
business environment for expressway operations, and the project expressway will also receive 
substantial equity injections from the central and provincial governments. As the Project will 
generate revenue in domestic currency, there is a risk related to exchange rate variations. 
However, sensitivity tests indicate that an adverse exchange rate change will have only a limited 
effect on the FIRR.

A.  Traffic Demand 
 
1.  Implementation of the economic reform policies since 1978 has resulted in rapid growth 
of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) economy, and a corresponding increase in the demand 
for transport services.1 Despite the Government's efforts to increase the country's transport 
capacity, serious constraints and bottlenecks remain, especially in the road subsector. By the 
end of 2000, the PRC transport system comprised about 68,000 kilometers (km) of railways, 
1.4 million km of highways, 119,300 km of inland waterways, and 1.5 million km of civil aviation 
routes. However, the density of the PRC transport network ranks among the lowest in the region 
relative to population or land area.2  
 
2.  The privately owned fleet of motor vehicles in the PRC increased more than 20 times 
during 1985–2000, from 0.3 million vehicles to 6.3 million. In 2000, the PRC vehicle fleet totaled 
15.5 million trucks, cars, and buses, and 46.5 million other motorized vehicles (special vehicles, 
tractors, and motorcycles). The total number of trucks, cars, and buses increased by about 
1.3 million in 2000, with the share for trucks dropping to 45.0%, down from 66.8% in 1990. 
Despite the rapid increase in total vehicles, the PRC has only about 1.3 vehicles (trucks, cars or 
buses) for 100 persons, which is low relative to other countries in the Asia and Pacific region. 
Until the early 1980s, there were no modern vehicles imported or joint ventures formed to 
introduce  modern  technology.  There  are  plans  to  invest  up  to  $7  billion  in  automotive 
manufacturing in the PRC between 2000 and 2005. The PRC’s accession to the World Trade 
Organization should increase investment in automobile production. The modernization of the 
vehicle fleet will improve vehicle safety and reduce fuel consumption and vehicle emissions.  
 
3.  Road freight traffic in Shanxi Province increased from 11.5 billion ton-km to 27.0 billion 
ton-km between 1990 and 2000. Road passenger traffic increased during the same period from 
5.9 billion passenger-km to 13.6 billion passenger-km, corresponding to an average annual 
growth rate of 8.9% and 8.7%, respectively, compared with the national growth rates of 5.9% 
and 9.7%. In Shanxi, privately owned motor vehicles in 2000 totaled about 235,078. Given the 
PRC's rapid economic growth and vehicle ownership, both the public and private vehicle fleets 
are expected to continue to grow rapidly in the coming years. This will result in substantial 
increases in the volume of road traffic and mounting congestion. The high share of slow-moving 
traffic,  mainly  tractors,  bicycles,  and  nonmotorized  agricultural  vehicles,  aggravates  road 
congestion, and is a major cause of traffic accidents. In 2000, Shanxi had about 555,000 trucks 
and passenger vehicles, equal to 3.6% of the national fleet. This translates into 1.71 vehicles 
per 100 persons in Shanxi, slightly above the national average.

SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT PLAN 
 
1.  The project expressway and local roads will affect 11 townships and 52 administrative 
villages in three counties: Xinjiang, Jishan, and Hejin. The Project is estimated to permanently 
occupy about 411 hectares as confirmed by the impact survey. The permanent land acquisition 
is equivalent to the loss of farmland of 3,568 people (850 households). Most of the households 
will regain similar farmland through land redistribution. About 5,200 sqm of structures, including 
54 houses, will be affected, necessitating relocation of 20 households. One enterprise will also 
lose its structure. 
 
2.  Land acquisition and resettlement impacts were minimized through the following actions: 
(i) aligning the expressway away from areas with high population densities and by avoiding 
historic relics; (ii) occupying wasteland, waste hills for alignment, where possible; (iii) avoiding 
villages  with  lower  per  capita  farmland;  (iv) reducing  the  amount  of  land  acquisition  for 
interchanges to the extent possible; and (v) protecting water conservancy and irrigation facilities 
as far as possible. Consultations were held with local officials to minimize resettlement effects 
during the setting of the alignment during the feasibility study and detailed study. 
 
3.  The Second Highway Design and Research Institute (SHDRI) under the Ministry of 
Communications  conducted  initial  socioeconomic  surveys  and  interviews  with  local 
governments and villagers in the project area from February 1998 to June 1999. In November–
December 2001, a resettlement expert group composed of staff from a local community and the 
SHDRI, as well as city and county government officials, conducted detailed land acquisition, 
census and socioeconomic surveys in the project influence area in conjunction with the Shanxi 
Communications Department (SCD). 
 
4.  For people unavoidably affected by the Project, the resettlement objective is to ensure 
attainment of equal or better livelihoods and living standards in line with the People’s Republic 
of China (PRC) Land Administration Law (1998) and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) policy 
on  involuntary  resettlement  (1995).  The  law  is  supplemented  by  the  Methods  for  Land 
Management and Execution in Shanxi Province (2000). The Executing Agency will ensure that 
any people losing land, housing or other assets and means of production will be assisted in 
restoring  their  incomes  and  living  standards  to  at  least  the  levels  without  the  Project’s 
intervention. Assets will either be replaced or their owners compensated at replacement cost. 
The total resettlement budget is about $31.2 million equivalent (CNY258.2 million). 
 
5.  Land compensation payments are calculated at eight times the annual average output 
value (AAOV) of the land over the past 3 years. A resettlement subsidy is calculated at five 
times AAOV over the past 3 years. Payment is made to the village commission. Young crops 
that cannot be harvested before land acquisition are compensated at average purchasing price 
per season of the crop compensation rate. Temporarily acquired land is paid the AAOV for each 
year of occupation. Topsoil is stored and then replaced in the original site at the end of 
occupation. The cost of restoring land to farmland will be paid by the Project; some payments 
can be made directly to the farmers for helping to restore these lands. 
 
6.  People losing houses will receive direct compensation according to the class and type of 
house. Compensation is based on the floor area and material, and there will be no depreciation 
of housing values, and the affected people will be allowed to salvage materials from their former 
houses without deduction from their  compensation. They can choose to construct their own 
house, or to request that the township or village arrange this for them. The new house is to be 
constructed and the family relocated before the former dwelling is demolished.

(iv)   Operation and maintenance costs include all incremental costs for operating the

ROAD SAFETY AND VEHICLE EMISSIONS  
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The reforms of 1978 have resulted in rapid growth of the People’s Republic of China 
(PRC) economy, and a corresponding increase in the demand for transport services. On the 
other hand, people and their surroundings are faced with the increasingly serious problem of 
road safety and vehicle emissions, which inhibit the economic and social development of the 
PRC. They are associated with millions of premature deaths and injuries, high medical costs, 
strain in welfare service, and reduction of productivity. Many of the problems encountered with 
road safety and vehicle emissions are predominantly institutional in nature, with fragmentation 
of  responsibility,  lack  of  interdepartmental  coordination,  inadequate  data  systems  and 
monitoring,  inadequate  action  plans  and  integrated  strategy,  inadequate  enforcement  and 
legislation,  lack  of  road  safety  audit  and  accident  black  spot  programs,  a  weak  vehicle 
inspection system, and a shortage of skilled staff and resources. For improvement of air quality 
in Shanxi, an advisory technical assistance (TA) was provided to the PRC in 1999.1 To improve 
traffic safety in PRC, an advisory TA was approved in 1999.2 For reduction of vehicle emissions, 
a regional TA was approved in 2000.3 ADB will continue its dialogue with the PRC Government 
to facilitate the implementation of the national action plans to be proposed under these TAs. 
 
B.  Road Safety 
 
2.  Accident rates in PRC are very high compared with highly motorized countries and 
DMCs of the region. Official statistics indicate that there were 616,971 road accidents, killing 
93,853 and injuring 418,721, in 2000, up 49%, 12%, and 46% respectively from the previous 
year. A recent study4 concluded that the economic cost of traffic accidents in the PRC may be 
as high as $2 billion per year, while another study5 indicates that underreporting of traffic 
accident fatalities in the PRC may be about 42%. Most accidents are associated with driver 
behavior, speed, alcohol intake, pedestrian action, and road conditions.6 There are no readily 
available data on comparative accident rates for various classes of road in Shanxi. The lack of 
coordination between departments and the poorly maintained traffic accident data are seriously 
hampering meaningful traffic safety reforms in the PRC. In 2000, Shanxi recorded 16,344 road 
accidents, involving 2,414 fatalities and 11,721 injuries. There was a rise of 13% in accidents over 
the previous year and accidents increased at a higher rate than traffic volume growth (about 
9.4%), due to the poor condition of the roads 
 
1.  Traffic and Road Design Standards

conjunction with others such as mobility, economy, and environmental impacts, to achieve

carefully to ensure that speed limits are chosen to suit the geometric design rather than the

2.  Organizational Structure 
 
4.  The two organizations concerned with road safety and enforcement of the existing 
expressways in Shanxi are the Expressway Subdivision of the Traffic Police of the Shanxi 
Public  Security  Department  (SPSD)  and  the  Enforcement  and  Emergency  Division  of  the 
Expressway Companies. Shanxi has a road safety council, which investigates all types of 
accidents and produces draft provincial codes and standards for accident prevention. While 
establishing the council is a significant step, there is a need to enhance the authority of this 
council to play more proactive role in coordinating road safety across the province.  
 
3.  Interdepartmental Coordination and Action Plan  
 
5.  It is necessary to establish an interdepartmental framework to enhance road safety in 
the province. While  Shanxi Hou-yu Expressway Construction Company Limited (SHEC) will 
concentrate on the engineering, road safety audit,  black spot, and operational issues of the 
expressway, involvement of  SPSD is essential. SHEC will establish a working relationship 
strategy with  SPSD to implement safer and better expressway operations. The strategy will 
seek to promote innovative ways to improve road safety through the following broad-based 
approach  (i) institutional  strengthening:  strengthen  the  provincial  road  safety  council  by 
establishing an interdepartmental executive group; develop comprehensive action programs, 
technical studies, and modalities for greater leadership and awareness; and improve the policy 
and regulatory framework and effective monitoring; (ii) capacity building and human resources 
development: set up an effective and uniform database; and upgrade skills and knowledge, and 
road  safety  research;  (iii)  provincial  cooperation:  develop  potential  common  projects  and 
activities, conduct regional workshops, disseminate best practice, and strengthen linkages in the 
national program; and (iv) create an effective coordination approach through government and 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs), the private sector, and community groups. This will be 
achieved  through  (i) a  computerized  accident  and  enforcement  reporting  and  monitoring 
system; (ii) development of a strategy framework and performance indicators; (iii) staff training; 
and (iv) strengthening the role of the provincial road safety council.  
 
6.  An implementation plan is required to promote an efficient road safety strategy in the 
province, and for the expressway. An integrated approach may be adopted to facilitate the 
implementation of the action plan by involving  SCD and SPSD. Insurance companies,  the 
private sector, and NGO groups can also be involved. This will result in: (i) reduction of 
accidents;  (ii)  reduced  demand  on  emergency  and  hospital  services;  and  (iii)  improved 
productivity. Formulation of a better  system and other measures will generate revenues to 
support the program. Modification of the vehicle-testing centre also will provide some funds to 
support  the  proposed  program.  A  road  safety  specialist  in  safety  strategy  development, 
enforcement management, prevention measures, socioeconomic cost, and critical issues of 
successful road safety programs will assist SPSD and SHEC for a period of 2 person-months. 
The specialist will (i) develop a general provincial road safety implementation plan covering all

key issues; and (ii) formulate a road safety strategy for the project area, e.g., Hejin, Jishan, and 
Xinjiang. 
C.  Vehicle Emissions 
 
7.  Motor vehicle emissions are a significant contributor to air pollution. The fragmentation of 
responsibility, lack of interdepartmental coordination, together with inadequate base data and 
monitoring system prevent the formulation of any specific targets for reduction in key pollutants 
such as CO, NO , PM , and nonmethane  hydrocarbons  (NMHC). Given these conditions, 
x 10
SHEC and the Yuncheng Environmental Protection Bureau will proceed with the planning for a 
vehicle  emissions  control  implementation  plan.  Implementing  such  a  program  will  require 
cooperative effort among a number of agencies, jurisdictions,  and communities as well as 
government commitment and leadership. The recommended approach is to implement a pilot 
vehicle emission testing and certification program, focusing initially on diesel trucks,  buses, 
taxis, and  later on for  all vehicles. The program then could be assessed and adapted for 
areawide implementation. The pilot program could include (i) identification of vehicle types; (ii) 
establishment of vehicle inspection sites; (iii) building more CNG filling stations; (iv) a public 
awareness campaign regarding the inspection timetable for vehicles, based on license plate 
numbers and advertisement of economic incentives, e.g., toll reductions for certified vehicles; 
(v) an intensive training program and capacity building focusing on emissions testing, and data 
analysis and reporting; (vi) an annual air quality monitoring program; (vi) media, NGO, and 
community involvement; and (vi) establishment of an integrated provincial level emission control 
council. 
 
8.  An implementation plan is required to promote  efficient  vehicle  emissions reduction 
measures in the province and in the project area. An integrated approach may be adopted to 
facilitate the implementation of  the action plan. Various  agencies such as SHEC, Yuncheng 
Environmental Protection Bureau, and SPSD need to participate  in the implementation of the 
plan. Fuel companies, the private sector, and NGO groups can also be involved. Modification of 
current programs of the environmental bureau and optimization of resources is necessary to 
enhance emissions reductions in the project area. Formulation of a better  system and other 
measures will generate some revenues to support the program. Further development of current 
vehicle testing centers to create an integrated vehicle testing system (both safety and vehicle 
emissions) will be a cost-effective method to support the program. 
  
9.  A  vehicle  emissions  specialist  will  be  engaged  to  undertake  consulting  services, 
covering emissions strategy development, enforcement management, prevention measures, 
socioeconomic  cost,  and  critical  issues  of  successful  emissions  control  programs.  The 
environmental protection bureau will take the lead in implementing the strategies, provide the 
necessary  services,  and  assign  senior  officials  to  ensure  smooth  implementation  and 
coordination with all parties.
